content: Mr. Schiller’s dismissive statements around ubiquitous voice concern me. The appeal of an Echo is that it’s becoming a part of the family experience. That it’s NOT just mine. Also, the Echo is not about replacing screens or being stuck to the kitchen. It’s about ubiquity. And of course we’ll always need and want screens. It’s similar to how textbooks have text and images: a picture says more than thousand words; but still our textbooks use both, aren’t just all images. There’s pros and cons for both, depending on the situation. Even if Apple fixes the broken “Hey Siri”, an iPhone in my pocket won’t be able to speak back to me if it stays there, and devices constantly in my ear (AirPods, as fascinating as they are) can’t be the answer at home. I just hope Apple has ideas for fixing assistant computing at home. Today, Apple offers nothing. Amazon has pulled something off that was profoundly Apple: take existing technology (speakers, microphones, speech recognition, a voice assistant) and create something better out of it, impressing the world with ingenious simplicity and usefulness. I’m waiting for the next time Apple will be Apple again.
